dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comes this night to Messina.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off when I left him.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: But few of any sort, and none of name.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers. I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by Don Pedro. He hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age, doing in the figure of a lamb the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better bettered expectation than you must expect of me to tell you how.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I have already delivered him letters, and there appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could not show itself modest enough without a badge of bitterness.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Did he break out into tears?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: In great measure.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: A kind overflow of kindness. There are no faces truer than those that are so washed; how much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the wars or no?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such in the army of any sort.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What is he that you ask for, niece?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: O! he is returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath he killed? for, indeed, I promised to eat all of his killing.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it; he is a very valiant trencher-man; he hath an excellent stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: And a good soldier too, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: And a good soldier to a lady; but what is he to a lord?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all honourable virtues.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: It is so indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man; but for the stuffing,-well, we are all mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her; they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit between them.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man governed with one! so that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him bear it for a difference between himself and his horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the next block.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No; and he were, I would burn my study. But I pray you, who is his companion? Is there no young squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere he be cured.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I will hold friends with you, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Do, good friend.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: You will never run mad, niece.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No, not till a hot January.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Don Pedro is approached. Balthasar and Others.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your Grace, for trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Her mother hath many times told me so.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this what you are, being a man. Truly the lady fathers herself. Be happy, lady, for you are like an honourable father.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior Benedick: nobody marks you.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: What! my dear Lady Disdain, are you yet living?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Is it possible Disdain should die while she hath such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick? Courtesy itself must convert to disdain if you come in her presence.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted; and I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart; for, truly, I love none.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: A dear happiness to women: they would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that. I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind; so some gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate scratched face.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Scratching could not make it worse, and 'twere such a face as yours were.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's name; I have done.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: That is the sum of all, Leonato: Signior Claudio, and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartly prays some occasion may detain us longer: I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.  Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to the Prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Please it your Grace lead on?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Is she not a modest young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise; only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me truly how thou likest her.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Can the world buy such a jewel?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad brow, or do you play the flouting Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder, and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take you, to go in the song?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such matter: there's her cousin and she were not possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the last of December. But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn to the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Is't come to this, in faith? Hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a bachelor of threescore again? Go to, i' faith; and thou wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away Sundays. Look! Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonato's?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I would your Grace would constrain me to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb man; I would have you think so; but on my allegiance mark you this, on my allegiance: he is in love. With who? now that is your Grace's part. Mark how short his answer is: with Hero, Leonato's short daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If this were so, so were it uttered.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Like the old tale, my lord: ‘it is not so, nor 'twas not so; but indeed, God forbid it should be so.'

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: By my troth, I speak my thought.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: That I love her, I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: That she is worthy, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: That I neither feel how she should be loved, nor know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks; but that I will have a recheat winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the right to trust none; and the fine is,-for the which I may go the finer,-I will live a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord; not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of blind Cupid.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove a notable argument.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder and called Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Well, as time shall try: ‘In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.'

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set them in my forehead; and let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write, ‘Here is good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign ‘Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I look for an earthquake too then.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Well, you will temporize with the hours. In the meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made great preparation.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage; and so I commit you-

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: To the tuition of God: from my house, if I had it,-

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: The sixth of July: your loving friend, Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere you flout old ends any further, examine your conscience: and so I leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: My liege, your Highness now may do me good.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: No child but Hero; she's his only heir. Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O! my lord, When you went onward on this ended action, I looked upon her with a soldier's eye, That lik'd, but had a rougher task in hand Than to drive liking to the name of love; But now I am return'd, and that war-thoughts Have left their places vacant, in their rooms Come thronging soft and delicate desires, All prompting me how fair young Hero is, Saying, I lik'd her ere I went to wars.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Thou wilt be like a lover presently, And tire the hearer with a book of words. If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her, and with her father, And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: How sweetly you do minister to love, That know love's grief by his complexion! But lest my liking might too sudden seem, I would have salv'd it with a longer treatise.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What need the bridge much broader than the flood? The fairest grant is the necessity. Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lov'st, And I will fit thee with the remedy. I know we shall have revelling tonight: I will assume thy part in some disguise, And tell fair Hero I am Claudio; And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart, And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale: Then after to her father will I break; And the conclusion is, she shall be thine. In practice let us put it presently.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: How now, brother? Where is my cousin your son? Hath he provided this music?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Are they good?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: As the event stamps them: but they have a good cover; they show well outward. The Prince and Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in my orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine: the Prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance; and if he found her accordant, he meant to take the present time by the top and instantly break with you of it.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and question him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the better prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it. Cousins, you know what you have to do. O! I cry you mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will use your skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy time.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out of measure sad?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds; therefore the sadness is without limit.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: You should hear reason.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: And when I have heard it, what blessings brings it?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I wonder that thou (being as thou say'st thou art, born under Saturn) goest about to apply a moral medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad when I have cause, and smile at no man's jests; eat when I have stomach, and wait for no man's leisure; sleep when I am drowsy, and tend on no man's business; laugh when I am merry, and claw no man in his humour.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Yea; but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controlment. You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace; and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do my liking: in the meantime, let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Can you make no use of your discontent?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes here? What news, Borachio?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: I came yonder from a great supper: the Prince your brother is royally entertained by Leonato; and I can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Even he.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks he?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in sad conference: I whipt me behind the arras, and there heard it agreed upon that the Prince should woo Hero for himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Come, come; let us thither: this may prove food to my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way. You are both sure, and will assist me?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: To the death, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of my mind! Shall we go to prove what's to be done?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: We'll wait upon your Lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Was not Count John here at supper?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I saw him not.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: He were an excellent man that were made just in the mid-way between him and Benedick: the one is too like an image, and says nothing; and the other too like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior Benedick's face-

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world if a' could get her good will.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: In faith, she's too curst.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's sending that way; for it is said, ‘God sends a curst cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and evening. Lord! I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel and make him my waiting gentlewoman? He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man; and he that is more than a youth is not for me; and he that is less than a man, I am not for him: therefore I will even take sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his apes into hell.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Well then, go you into hell?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No; but to the gate; and there will the Devil meet me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and say, ‘Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here's no place for you maids.' So deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the heavens: he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your father.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy, and say, ‘Father, as it please you:'- but yet for all that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy, and say, ‘Father, as it please me.'

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Not till God make men of some other metal than earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be over-mastered with a piece of valiant dust? to make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl? No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren; and truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the Prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed in good time: if the Prince be too important, tell him there is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero: wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace: the first suit is hot and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical; the wedding, mannerly modest, as a measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes Repentance, and with his bad legs, falls into the cinquepace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I have a good eye, uncle: I can see a church by daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room. John, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing, I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: With me in your company?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: I may say so, when I please.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And when please you to say so?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute should be like the case!

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Why, then, your visor should be thatch'd.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Speak low, if you speak love.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Well, I would you did like me.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many ill qualities.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Which is one?

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: I say my prayers aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: I love you the better; the hearers may cry Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: God match me with a good dancer!

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done! Answer, clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: No more words: the clerk is answered.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: I know you well enough: you are Signior Antonio.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: At a word, I am not.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: I know you by the waggling of your head.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you are he, you are he.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: At a word, I am not.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Come, come; do you think I do not know you by your excellent wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an end.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Will you not tell me who told you so?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: No, you shall pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit out of the ‘Hundred Merry Tales.' Well, this was Signior Benedick that said so.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: What's he?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I am sure you know him well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Not I, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Did he never make you laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I pray you, what is he?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Why, he is the Prince's jester: a very dull fool; only his gift is in devising impossible slanders: none but libertines delight in him; and the commendation is not in his wit, but in his villainy; for he both pleases men and angers them, and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in the fleet: I would he had boarded me!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me; which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night.  We must follow the leaders.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: In every good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Are you not Signior Benedick?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: You know me well; I am he.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love: he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him from her; she is no equal for his birth: you may do the part of an honest man in it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: How know you he loves her?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I heard him swear his affection.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Come, let us to the banquet.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thus answer I in name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio. 'Tis certain so; the Prince wooss for himself. Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love: Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues; Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood. This is an accident of hourly proof, Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Count Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yea, the same.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Come, will you go with me?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Whither?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Even to the next willow, about your own business, Count. What fashion will you wear the garland of? About your neck, like a usurer's chain? or under your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear it one way, for the Prince hath got your Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I wish him joy of her.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they sell bullocks. But did you think the Prince would have served you thus?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I pray you, leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Alas! poor hurt fowl. Now will he creep into sedges. But, that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The Prince's fool! Ha! it may be I go under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it is the base though bitter disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person, and so gives me out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Now, signior, where's the Count? Did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren. I told him, and I think I told him true, that your Grace had got the good will of this young lady; and I offered him my company to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: To be whipped! What's his fault?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: The flat transgression of a school-boy, who, being overjoy'd with finding a bird's nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression is in the stealer.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the garland too; for the garland he might have worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take it, have stolen his bird's nest.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to the owner.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say honestly.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: O! she misused me past the endurance of a block: an oak but with one green leaf on it would have answered her: my very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the Prince's jester, that I was duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me, that I stood like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the north star. I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make the fire too. Come, talk not of her; you shall find her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some scholar would conjure her, for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose because they would go thither; so indeed, all disquiet, horror and perturbation follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Look! here she comes.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Will your Grace command me any service to the world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on; I will fetch you a toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia; bring you the length of Prester John's foot; fetch you a hair off the Great Cham's beard; do you any embassage to the Pygmies, rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy. You have no employment for me?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: None, but to desire your good company.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot endure my Lady Tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of Signior Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave him use for it, a double heart for a single one: marry, once before he won it of me with false dice, therefore your Grace may well say I have lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Why, how now, Count! wherefore are you sad?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Not sad, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: How then? Sick?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Neither, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well; but civil Count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true; though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won; I have broke with her father, and, his good will obtained; name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes: his Grace hath made the match, and all grace say Amen to it!

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Speak, Count, 'tis your cue.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And so she doth, cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes everyone to the world but I, and I am sunburnt. I may sit in a corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I would rather have one of your father's getting. Hath your Grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Will you have me, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days: your Grace is too costly to wear every day. But, I beseech your Grace, pardon me; I was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best becomes you; for out of question, you were born in a merry hour.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there was a star danced, and under that was I born. Cousins, God give you joy!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your Grace's pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: By my troth, a pleasant spirited lady.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps; and not ever sad then, for I have heard my daughter say, she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O! by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O Lord! my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Count Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, my lord. Time goes on crutches till love have all his rites.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just seven-night; and a time too brief too, to have all things answer my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing; but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules' labours, which is, to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection the one with the other. I would fain have it a match; and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall give you direction.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And I, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And you too, gentle Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble strain, of approved valour, and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no longer an archer: his glory shall be ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Show me briefly how.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: I think I told your lordship, a year since, how much I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the Prince your brother; spare not to tell him, that he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned Claudio,-whose estimation do you mightily hold up,-to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: What proof shall I make of that?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato. Look you for any other issue?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Only to despite them, I will endeavour anything.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Go then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as-in love of your brother's honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid,-that you have discovered thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial: offer them instances, which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding: for in the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent; and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty, that jealousy shall be called assurance, and all the preparation overthrown.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in practice. Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a thousand ducats.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Boy!

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Signior?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: In my chamber window lies a book; bring it hither to me in the orchard.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: I am here already, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again. I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviours to love, will, after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others, become the argument of his own scorn by falling in love: and such a man is Claudio. I have known, when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe: I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake, carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many strange dishes. May I be so converted, and see with these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster; but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what colour it please God. Ha! the Prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour. and Musicians.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Come, shall we hear this music?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is, As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O! very well, my lord: the music ended, We'll fit the kid-fox with a penny-worth.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: O! good my lord, tax not so bad a voice To slander music any more than once.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: It is the witness still of excellency, To put a strange face on his own perfection. I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing; Since many a wooer doth commence his suit To her he thinks not worthy; yet he wooes; Yet will he swear he loves.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nay, pray thee come; Or if thou wilt hold longer argument, Do it in notes.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Note this before my notes; There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Why these are very crotchets that he speaks; Notes, notes, forsooth, and nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it not strange that sheep's guts should hale souls out of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when all's done. BALTHASAR  Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more, Men were deceivers ever; One foot in sea, and one on shore, To one thing constant never. Then sigh not so, but let them go, And be you blithe and bonny, Converting all your sounds of woe Into Hey nonny, nonny. Sing no more ditties, sing no mo Of dumps so dull and heavy; The fraud of men was ever so, Since summer first was leavy. Then sigh not so, but let them go, And be you blithe and bonny, Converting all your sounds of woe Into Hey nonny, nonny.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: By my troth, a good song.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: And an ill singer, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And he had been a dog that should have howled thus, they would have hanged him; and I pray God his bad voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the night-raven, come what plague could have come after it. DON PEDRO. Yea, marry; dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee, get us some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber window.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: The best I can, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Do so: farewell. Come hither, Leonato: what was it you told me of today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O! ay:- Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits. I did never think that lady would have loved any man.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviours seemed ever to abhor.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it but that she loves him with an enraged affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Maybe she doth but counterfeit.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Faith, like enough.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O God! counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Bait the hook well: this fish will bite.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What effects, my lord? She will sit you;  You heard my daughter tell you how.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: She did, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: How, how, I pray you? You amaze me: I would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially against Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I should think this a gull, but that the white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot, sure, hide itself in such reverence.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: ‘Shall I,' says she, ‘that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: This says she now when she is beginning to write to him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told us of.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O! when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: That.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O! she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence; railed at herself, that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her: ‘I measure him,' says she, ‘by my own spirit; for I should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I love him, I should.'

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; ‘O sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: She doth indeed; my daughter says so; and the ecstasy hath so much overborne her, that my daughter is sometimes afeard she will do a desperate outrage to herself. It is very true.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she will not discover it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: To what end? he would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And she is exceeding wise.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: In everything but in loving Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O! my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me; I would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear what he will say.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Were it good, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her, rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: She doth well: if she should make tender of her love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the man,-as you know all,-hath a contemptible spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: He is a very proper man.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: 'Fore God, and in my mind, very wise.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And I take him to be valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes them with a most Christian-like fear.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace: if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God, howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests he will make. Well, I am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with good counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter: let it cool the while. I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never trust my expectation.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Let there be the same net spread for her; and that must your daughter and her gentlewoman carry. The sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the scene that I would see, which will be merely a dumb show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: This can be no trick: the conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it seems her affections have their full bent. Love me? why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured: they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive the love come from her; they say too that she will rather die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy are they that hear their detractions, and can put them to mending. They say the lady is fair: 'tis a truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous: 'tis so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving me: by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love with her. I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me, because I have railed so long against marriage; but doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the career of his humour? No; the world must be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day! she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in her.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would not have come.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: You take pleasure then in the message?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's point, and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, signior: fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Ha! ‘Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner,' there's a double meaning in that. ‘I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me,' that's as much as to say, Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlour; There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the Prince and Claudio: Whisper her ear, and tell her, I and Ursala Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us, And bid her steal into the pleached bower, Where honey-suckles, ripen'd by the sun, Forbid the sun to enter; like favourites, Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it. There will she hide her, To listen our propose. This is thy office; Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick: When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit. My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice: of this matter Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made, That only wounds by hearsay. Now begin; For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish Cut with her golden oars the silver stream, And greedily devour the treacherous bait: So angle we for Beatrice; who even now Is couched in the woodbine coverture. Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful; I know her spirits are as coy and wild As haggards of the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it; But I persuaded them, if they lov'd Benedick, To wish him wrestle with affection, And never to let Beatrice know of it.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: O god of love! I know he doth deserve As much as may be yielded to a man; But Nature never fram'd a woman's heart Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice; Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprising what they look on, and her wit Values itself so highly, that to her All matter else seems weak. She cannot love, Nor take no shape nor project of affection, She is so self-endear'd.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Sure I think so; And therefore certainly it were not good She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man, How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur'd, But she would spell him backward: if fair-fac'd, She would swear the gentleman should be her sister; If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antick, Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed; If low, an agate very vilely cut; If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds; If silent, why, a block moved with none. So turns she every man the wrong side out, And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: No; not to be so odd, and from all fashions, As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable. But who dare tell her so? If I should speak, She would mock me into air: O! she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit. Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly: It were a better death than die with mocks, Which is as bad as die with tickling.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: No; rather I will go to Benedick, And counsel him to fight against his passion. And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with. One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: O! do not do your cousin such a wrong. She cannot be so much without true judgment,- Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is priz'd to have,-as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam, Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick, For shape, for bearing, argument and valour, Goes foremost in report through Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it. When are you married, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Why, every day, tomorrow. Come, go in: I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: She's lim'd, I warrant you, We have caught her, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: If it prove so, then loving goes by haps: Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true? Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much? Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu! No glory lives behind the back of such. And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee, Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand: If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee To bind our loves up in a holy band; For others say thou dost deserve, and I Believe it better than reportingly.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe me.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage, as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth; he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bowstring, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him. He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper; for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: So say I: methinks you are sadder.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I hope he be in love.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in him to be truly touched with love. If he be sad, he wants money.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I have the tooth-ache.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Draw it.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Hang it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What! sigh for the tooth-ache?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Where is but a humour or a worm?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Well, everyone can master a grief but he that has it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yet say I, he is in love.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow; or in the shape of two countries at once, as a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs: a' brushes his hat a mornings; what should that bode?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him; and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Indeed he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him out by that?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: That's as much as to say the sweet youth's in love.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And when was he wont to wash his face?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear what they say of him.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into a lute-string, and now governed by stops.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude he is in love.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Nay, but I know who loves him.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yes, and his ill conditions; and in despite of all, dies for him.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Yet is this no charm for the tooth-ache. Old signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight or nine wise words to speak to you, which these hobby-horses must not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: My lord and brother, God save you!

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good den, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: In private?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: If it please you; yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I would speak of concerns him.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Means your lordship to be married tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: You know he does.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: You may think I love you not: let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage; surely suit ill-spent and labour ill bestowed!

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Why, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I came hither to tell you; and circumstances shortened,-for she has been too long a talking of,-the lady is disloyal.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Who, Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Even she: Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Disloyal?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: The word's too good to paint out her wickedness; I could say, she were worse: think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till further warrant: go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding-day: if you love her then, tomorrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour to change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: May this be so?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I will not think it.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know. If you will follow me, I will show you enough; and when you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her tomorrow, in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show itself.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: O day untowardly turned!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O mischief strangely thwarting!

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: O plague right well prevented! So will you say when you have seen the sequel.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Are you good men and true?

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the Prince's watch.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacoal; for they can write and read.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Come hither, neighbour Seacoal. God hath blessed you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is the gift of Fortune; but to write and read comes by Nature.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Both which, Master Constable,-

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it; and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lanthorn. This is your charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any man stand, in the Prince's name.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: How, if a' will not stand?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and presently call the rest of the watch together, and thank God you are rid of a knave.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince's subjects.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in the streets: for, for the watch to babble and to talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what belongs to a watch.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend; only have a care that your bills be not stolen. Well, you are to call at all the alehouses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: How if they will not?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Why then, let them alone till they are sober: if they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your office, to be no true man; and, for such kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them, why, the more is for your honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they that touch pitch will be defiled. The most peaceable way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man who hath any honesty in him.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call to the nurse and bid her still it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Why then, depart in peace, and let the child wake her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baes, will never answer a calf when he bleats.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: 'Tis very true.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: This is the end of the charge. You constable, are to present the Prince's own person: if you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Nay, by'r lady, that I think, a' cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Five shillings to one on't, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without the Prince be willing; for, indeed, the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offence to stay a man against his will.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: By'r lady, I think it be so.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Ha, ah, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your fellows' counsels and your own, and good night. Come, neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here upon the church bench till two, and then all to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
