dialogues.line: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you, watch about Signior Leonato's door; for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu; be vigitant, I beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: What, Conrade!

dialogues.speaker: Watch
dialogues.line: Peace! stir not.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Conrade, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Here, man. I am at thy elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a scab follow.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: I will owe thee an answer for that; and now forward with thy tale.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Stand thee close then under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Watch
dialogues.line: Some treason, masters; yet stand close.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Therefore know, I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich; for when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: I wonder at it.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Yes, it is apparel.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: I mean, the fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?

dialogues.speaker: Watch
dialogues.line: I know that Deformed; a' has been a vile thief this seven years; a' goes up and down like a gentleman: I remember his name.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Didst thou not hear somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: No: 'twas the vane on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is? how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty? sometime fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy painting; sometime like god Bel's priests in the old church window; sometime like the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Not so neither; but know, that I have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress' chamber window, bids me a thousand times good night,-I tell this tale vilely:-I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio, and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio; but the devil my master, knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged; swore he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning at the temple, and there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o'er night, and send her home again without a husband.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: We charge you in the Prince's name, stand!

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Call up the right Master Constable. We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him, a' wears a lock.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Masters, masters!

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Masters,-

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of these men's bills.

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll obey you.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: I will, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: And bid her come hither.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Well.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Troth, I think your other rebato were better.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: By my troth's not so good; and I warrant your cousin will say so.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear none but this.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: O! that exceeds, they say.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: By my troth 's but a night-gown in respect of yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts round, underborne with a bluish tinsel; but for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on't.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is exceeding heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord honourable without marriage? I think you would have me say, saving your reverence, ‘a husband:' an bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend nobody. Is there any harm in ‘the heavier for a husband'? None, I think, and it be the right husband and the right wife; otherwise 'tis light, and not heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she comes.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Good morrow, coz.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Why, how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Clap's into ‘Light o' love'; that goes without a burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Ye, light o' love with your heels! then, if your husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall lack no barnes.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; 'tis time you were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: For the letter that begins them all, H.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more sailing by the star.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: What means the fool, trow?

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Nothing I; but God send everyone their heart's desire!

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: These gloves the Count sent me; they are an excellent perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I am stuffed, cousin, I cannot smell.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you professed apprehension?

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Ever since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely!

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your cap. By my troth, I am sick.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Get you some of this distilled Carduus benedictus, and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: There thou prick'st her with a thistle.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Benedictus! why benedictus? you have some moral in this benedictus.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I meant, plain holy thistle. You may think, perchance, that I think you are in love: nay, by'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list; nor I list not to think what I can; nor, indeed, I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love, or that you will be in love, or that you can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man: he swore he would never marry; and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging: and how you may be converted, I know not; but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Not a false gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you, that decerns you nearly.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with me.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Marry, this it is, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What is it, my good friends?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would desire they were; but, in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Yes, I thank God, I am as honest as any man living, that is an old man and no honester than I.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Neighbours, you are tedious.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the poor Duke's officers; but truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: All thy tediousness on me! ah?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Yea, and 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for I hear as good exclamation on your worship, as of any man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: And so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I would fain know what you have to say.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in Messina.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: A good old man, sir; he will be talking; as they say, ‘when the age is in, the wit is out.' God help us! it is a world to see! Well said, i' faith, neighbour Verges: well, God's a good man; and two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest soul, i' faith, sir; by my troth he is, as ever broke bread; but God is to be worshipped: all men are not alike; alas! good neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Gifts that God gives.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I must leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examined before your worship.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Take their examination yourself, and bring it me: I am now in great haste, as may appear unto you.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: It shall be suffigance.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I'll wait upon them: I am ready.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Go, good partner, go get you to Francis Seacoal; bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we are now to examination these men.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: And we must do it wisely.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you; here's that shall drive some of them to a non-come: only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication, and meet me at the gaol.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Come, Friar Francis, be brief: only to the plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: To be married to her, friar; you come to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Lady, you come hither to be married to this Count?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: If either of you know any inward impediment, why you should not be conjoined, I charge you, on your souls, to utter it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Know you any, Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: None, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Know you any, Count?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I dare make his answer; none.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O! what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do, not knowing what they do!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: How now! Interjections? Why then, some be of laughing, as ah! ha! he!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Stand thee by, Friar. Father, by your leave: Will you with free and unconstrained soul Give me this maid, your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And what have I to give you back whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nothing, unless you render her again.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness. There, Leonato, take her back again: Give not this rotten orange to your friend; She's but the sign and semblance of her honour. Behold! how like a maid she blushes here. O! what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withal. Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear, All you that see her, that she were a maid, By these exterior shows? But she is none: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed; Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What do you mean, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Not to be married, Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof, Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth, And made defeat of her virginity,-

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I know what you would say: if I have known her, You will say she did embrace me as a husband, And so extenuate the forehand sin: No, Leonato, I never tempted her with word too large; But as a brother to his sister show'd Bashful sincerity and comely love.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: And seem'd I ever otherwise to you?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it: You seem to me as Dian in her orb, As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown; But you are more intemperate in your blood Than Venus, or those pamper'd animals That rage in savage sensuality.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What should I speak? I stand dishonour'd, that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: This looks not like a nuptial.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: True! O God!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Leonato, stand I here? Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince's brother? Is this face Hero's? Are our eyes our own?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: All this is so; but what of this, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Let me but move one question to your daughter, And by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: O, God defend me! how am I beset! What kind of catechizing call you this?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: To make you answer truly to your name.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name With any just reproach?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Marry, that can Hero: Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue. What man was he talk'd with you yesternight Out at your window, betwixt twelve and one? Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: I talk'd with no man at that hour, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato, I am sorry you must hear: upon my honour, Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count, Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night, Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window; Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain, Confess'd the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret.

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Fie, fie! they are not to be nam'd, my lord, Not to be spoke of; There is not chastity enough in language Without offence to utter them. Thus, pretty lady, I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou been, If half thy outward graces had been plac'd About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart! But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! farewell, Thou pure impiety, and impious purity! For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love, And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang, To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm, And never shall it more be gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?

dialogues.speaker: Don John
dialogues.line: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: How doth the lady?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Dead, I think! Help, uncle! Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand: Death is the fairest cover for her shame That may be wish'd for.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: How now, cousin Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Have comfort, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Dost thou look up?

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Yea; wherefore should she not?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny The story that is printed in her blood? Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes; For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die, Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames, Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches, Strike at thy life. Griev'd I, I had but one? Chid I for that at frugal Nature's frame? O! one too much by thee. Why had I one? Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes? Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar's issue at my gates, Who smirched thus, and mir'd with infamy, I might have said, ‘No part of it is mine; This shame derives itself from unknown loins?' But mine, and mine I lov'd, and mine I prais'd, And mine that I was proud on, mine so much That I myself was to myself not mine, Valuing of her; why, she-O! she is fallen Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea Hath drops too few to wash her clean again, And salt too little which may season give To her foul tainted flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Sir, sir, be patient. For my part, I am so attir'd in wonder, I know not what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: O! on my soul, my cousin is belied!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No, truly, not; although, until last night, I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Confirm'd, confirm'd! O! that is stronger made, Which was before barr'd up with ribs of iron. Would the two princes lie? and Claudio lie, Who lov'd her so, that, speaking of her foulness, Wash'd it with tears? Hence from her! let her die.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Hear me a little; For I have only been silent so long, And given way unto this course of fortune, By noting of the lady: I have mark'd A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face; a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness bear away those blushes; And in her eye there hath appear'd a fire, To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool; Trust not my reading nor my observations, Which with experimental seal doth warrant The tenure of my book; trust not my age, My reverence, calling, nor divinity, If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here Under some biting error.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Friar, it cannot be. Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left Is that she will not add to her damnation A sin of perjury: she not denies it. Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse That which appears in proper nakedness?

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Lady, what man is he you are accus'd of?

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: They know that do accuse me, I know none; If I know more of any man alive Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant, Let all my sins lack mercy! O, my father! Prove you that any man with me convers'd At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight Maintain'd the change of words with any creature, Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Two of them have the very bent of honour; And if their wisdoms be misled in this, The practice of it lives in John the bastard, Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I know not. If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honour, The proudest of them shall well hear of it. Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine, Nor age so eat up my invention, Nor fortune made such havoc of my means, Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends, But they shall find, awak'd in such a kind, Both strength of limb and policy of mind, Ability in means and choice of friends, To quit me of them throughly.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case. Your daughter here the princes left for dead; Let her awhile be secretly kept in, And publish it that she is dead indeed: Maintain a mourning ostentation; And on your family's old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: What shall become of this? What will this do?

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf Change slander to remorse; that is some good. But not for that dream I on this strange course, But on this travail look for greater birth. She dying, as it must be so maintain'd, Upon the instant that she was accus'd, Shall be lamented, pitied and excus'd Of every hearer; for it so falls out That what we have we prize not to the worth Whiles we enjoy it, but being lack'd and lost, Why, then we rack the value, then we find The virtue that possession would not show us Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio: When he shall hear she died upon his words, The idea of her life shall sweetly creep Into his study of imagination, And every lovely organ of her life Shall come apparell'd in more precious habit, More moving, delicate, and full of life Into the eye and prospect of his soul, Than when she liv'd indeed: then shall he mourn,- If ever love had interest in his liver,- And wish he had not so accused her, No, though he thought his accusation true. Let this be so, and doubt not but success Will fashion the event in better shape Than I can lay it down in likelihood. But if all aim but this be levell'd false, The supposition of the lady's death Will quench the wonder of her infamy: And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,- As best befits her wounded reputation,- In some reclusive and religious life, Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you: And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio, Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Being that I flow in grief, The smallest twine may lead me.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: 'Tis well consented: presently away; For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. Come, lady, die to live: this wedding day Perhaps is but prolong'd: have patience and endure.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I will not desire that.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You have no reason; I do it freely.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Ah! how much might the man deserve of me that would right her.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Is there any way to show such friendship?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: A very even way, but no such friend.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: May a man do it?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: It is a man's office, but not yours.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I do love nothing in the world so well as you: is not that strange?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for me to say I loved nothing so well as you; but believe me not, and yet I lie not; I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Do not swear by it, and eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I will swear by it that you love me; and I will make him eat it that says I love not you.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Will you not eat your word?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love thee.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Why then, God forgive me!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: What offence, sweet Beatrice?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You have stayed me in a happy hour: I was about to protest I loved you.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And do it with all thy heart.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Come, bid me do anything for thee.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Kill Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Ha! not for the wide world.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I am gone, though I am here: there is no love in you: nay, I pray you, let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Beatrice,-

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: In faith, I will go.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: We'll be friends first.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Is Claudio thine enemy?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O! that I were a man. What! bear her in hand until they come to take hands, and then, with public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancour,-O God, that I were a man! I would eat his heart in the market-place.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Hear me, Beatrice,-

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Talk with a man out at a window! a proper saying!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Nay, but Beatrice,-

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Sweet Hero! she is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Beat-

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Princes and Counties! Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly Count Comfect; a sweet gallant, surely! O! that I were a man for his sake, or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies, valour into compliment, and men are only turned into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules, that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged Hero?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yea, as sure is I have a thought or a soul.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Enough! I am engaged, I will challenge him. I will kiss your hand, and so leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go, comfort your cousin: I must say she is dead; and so, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: O! a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: Which be the malefactors?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Marry, that am I and my partner.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Nay, that's certain: we have the exhibition to examine.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: But which are the offenders that are to be examined? let them come before Master Constable.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Yea, marry, let them come before me. What is your name, friend?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Borachio.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Pray write down Borachio. Yours, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Write down Master gentleman Conrade. Masters, do you serve God?

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: Yea, sir, we hope.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Write down that they hope they serve God: and write God first; for God defend but God should go before such villains! Masters, it is proved already that you are little better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so shortly. How answer you for yourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: A marvellous witty fellow, I assure you; but I will go about with him. Come you hither, sirrah; a word in your ear: sir, I say to you, it is thought you are false knaves.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Sir, I say to you we are none.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Well, stand aside. Fore God, they are both in a tale. Have you writ down, that they are none?

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine: you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. Let the watch come forth. Masters, I charge you, in the Prince's name, accuse these men.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince's brother, was a villain.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat perjury, to call a Prince's brother villain.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Master Constable,-

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Pray thee, fellow, peace: I do not like thy look, I promise thee.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: What heard you him say else?

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Yea, by the mass, that it is.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: What else, fellow?

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting redemption for this.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: This is all.

dialogues.speaker: Sexton
dialogues.line: And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away: Hero was in this manner accused, in this manner refused, and, upon the grief of this, suddenly died. Master Constable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonato's: I will go before and show him their examination.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Come, let them be opinioned.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Let them be in the hands-

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Off, coxcomb!

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: God's my life! where's the sexton? let him write down the Prince's officer coxcomb. Come, bind them. Thou naughty varlet!

dialogues.speaker: Conrade
dialogues.line: Away! you are an ass; you are an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my years? O that he were here to write me down an ass! but, masters, remember that I am an ass; though it be not written down, yet forget not that I am an ass. No, thou villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by good witness. I am a wise fellow; and, which is more, an officer; and, which is more, a householder; and, which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any in Messina; and one that knows the law, go to; and a rich fellow enough, go to; and a fellow that hath had losses; and one that hath two gowns, and everything handsome about him. Bring him away. O that I had been writ down an ass!

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I pray thee, cease thy counsel, Which falls into mine ears as profitless As water in a sieve: give not me counsel; Nor let no comforter delight mine ear But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine: Bring me a father that so lov'd his child, Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine, And bid him speak of patience; Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine, And let it answer every strain for strain, As thus for thus and such a grief for such, In every lineament, branch, shape, and form: If such a one will smile, and stroke his beard; Bid sorrow wag, cry ‘hem' when he should groan, Patch grief with proverbs; make misfortune drunk With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me, And I of him will gather patience. But there is no such man; for, brother, men Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it, Their counsel turns to passion, which before Would give preceptial medicine to rage, Fetter strong madness in a silken thread, Charm ache with air and agony with words. No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience To those that wring under the load of sorrow, But no man's virtue nor sufficiency To be so moral when he shall endure The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel: My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I pray thee peace! I will be flesh and blood; For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself; Make those that do offend you suffer too.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so. My soul doth tell me Hero is belied; And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince, And all of them that thus dishonour her.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good den, good den.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Good day to both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Hear you, my lords,-

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: We have some haste, Leonato.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord: Are you so hasty now?-well, all is one.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: If he could right himself with quarrelling, Some of us would lie low.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Who wrongs him?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou. Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword; I fear thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Marry, beshrew my hand, If it should give your age such cause of fear. In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Tush, tush, man! never fleer and jest at me: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As, under privilege of age, to brag What I have done being young, or what would do, Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head, Thou hast so wrong'd mine innocent child and me That I am forc'd to lay my reverence by, And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days, Do challenge thee to trial of a man. I say thou hast belied mine innocent child: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart, And she lies buried with her ancestors; O! in a tomb where never scandal slept, Save this of hers, fram'd by thy villainy!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: My villainy?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: You say not right, old man.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord, I'll prove it on his body, if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practice, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Away! I will not have to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill'd my child; If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed: But that's no matter; let him kill one first: Win me and wear me; let him answer me. Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me. Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence; Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Brother,-

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Content yourself. God knows I lov'd my niece; And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains, That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue. Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Brother Anthony,-

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea, And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple, Scambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boys, That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander, Go antickly, show outward hideousness, And speak off half a dozen dangerous words, How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst; And this is all!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: But, brother Anthony,-

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Come, 'tis no matter: Do not you meddle, let me deal in this.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience. My heart is sorry for your daughter's death; But, on my honour, she was charg'd with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I will not hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No? Come, brother, away. I will be heard.-

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Now, signior, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Good day, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Welcome, signior: you are almost come to part almost a fray.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Leonato and his brother. What think'st thou? Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: In a false quarrel there is no true valour. I came to seek you both.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: We have been up and down to seek thee; for we are high-proof melancholy, and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: It is in my scabbard; shall I draw it?

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Never any did so, though very many have been beside their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels; draw, to pleasure us.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou sick, or angry?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: What, courage, man! What though care killed a cat, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you charge it against me. I pray you choose another subject.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Nay then, give him another staff: this last was broke cross.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: By this light, he changes more and more: I think he be angry indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: God bless me from a challenge!

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: You are a villain, I jest not: I will make it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare. Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice. You have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me hear from you.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Well I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What, a feast, a feast?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid me to a calf's-head and a capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my knife's naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the other day. I said, thou hadst a fine wit. ‘True,' says she, ‘a fine little one.' ‘No,' said I, ‘a great wit.' ‘Right,' said she, ‘a great gross one.' ‘Nay,' said I, ‘a good wit.' ‘Just,' said she, ‘it hurts nobody.' ‘Nay,' said I, ‘the gentleman is wise.' ‘Certain,' said she, ‘a wise gentleman.' ‘Nay,' said I, ‘he hath the tongues.' ‘That I believe' said she, ‘for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning: there's a double tongue; there's two tongues.' Thus did she, an hour together, trans-shape thy particular virtues; yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the properest man in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Yea, that she did; but yet, for all that, an if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly. The old man's daughter told us all.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: All, all; and moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible Benedick's head?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yea, and text underneath, ‘Here dwells Benedick the married man!'

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Fare you well, boy: you know my mind. I will leave you now to your gossip-like humour; you break jests as braggarts do their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not. My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you: I must discontinue your company. Your brother the bastard is fled from Messina: you have, among you, killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord Lack-beard there, he and I shall meet; and till then, peace be with him.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: He is in earnest.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: And hath challenged thee?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Most sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: But, soft you; let me be: pluck up, my heart, and be sad! Did he not say my brother was fled? Conrade and Borachio.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance. Nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: How now! two of my brother's men bound! Borachio, one!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Officers, what offence have these men done?

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and to conclude, they are lying knaves.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee what's their offence; sixth and lastly, why they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Rightly reasoned, and in his own division; and, by my troth, there's one meaning well suited.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? This learned constable is too cunning to be understood. What's your offence?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer: do you hear me, and let this Count kill me. I have deceived even your very eyes: what your wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have brought to light; who, in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero; how you were brought into the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero's garments; how you disgraced her, when you should marry her. My villainy they have upon record; which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and my master's false accusation; and, briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: But did my brother set thee on to this?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Yea; and paid me richly for the practice of it.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: He is compos'd and fram'd of treachery: And fled he is upon this villainy.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I lov'd it first.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time our sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. And masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Verges
dialogues.line: Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes, That, when I note another man like him, I may avoid him. Which of these is he?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill'd Mine innocent child?

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: Yea, even I alone.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself: Here stand a pair of honourable men; A third is fled, that had a hand in it. I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death: Record it with your high and worthy deeds. 'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I know not how to pray your patience; Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself; Impose me to what penance your invention Can lay upon my sin: yet sinn'd I not But in mistaking.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: By my soul, nor I: And yet, to satisfy this good old man, I would bend under any heavy weight That he'll enjoin me to.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live; That were impossible; but, I pray you both, Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died; and if your love Can labour aught in sad invention, Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb, And sing it to her bones: sing it tonight. Tomorrow morning come you to my house, And since you could not be my son-in-law, Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter, Almost the copy of my child that's dead, And she alone is heir to both of us: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, And so dies my revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O noble sir, Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me! I do embrace your offer; and dispose For henceforth of poor Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming; Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret, Who, I believe, was pack'd in all this wrong, Hir'd to it by your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Borachio
dialogues.line: No, by my soul she was not; Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me; But always hath been just and virtuous In anything that I do know by her.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Moreover, sir,-which, indeed, is not under white and black,- this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass: I beseech you, let it be remembered in his punishment. And also, the watch heard them talk of one Deformed: they say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God's name, the which he hath used so long and never paid, that now men grow hard-hearted, and will lend nothing for God's sake. Pray you, examine him upon that point.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: There's for thy pains.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: God save the foundation!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

dialogues.speaker: Dogberry
dialogues.line: I leave an arrant knave with your worship; which I beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the example of others. God keep your worship! I wish your worship well; God restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart, and if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Farewell, my lords: we look for you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: We will not fail.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Tonight I'll mourn with Hero.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Bring you these fellows on. We'll talk with Margaret, How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come over it; for, in most comely truth, thou deservest it.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: To have no man come over me! why, shall I always keep below stairs?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth; it catches.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit, but hurt not.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt a woman: and so, I pray thee, call Beatrice. I give thee the bucklers.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Give us the swords, we have bucklers of our own.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with a vice; and they are dangerous weapons for maids.

dialogues.speaker: Margaret
dialogues.line: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And therefore will come. The god of love, That sits above, And knows me, and knows me, How pitiful I deserve,- I mean, in singing: but in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole book full of these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rime; I have tried: I can find out no rime to ‘lady' but ‘baby', an innocent rime; for ‘scorn,' ‘horn', a hard rime; for ‘school', ‘fool', a babbling rime; very ominous endings: no, I was not born under a riming planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms. Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Yea, signior; and depart when you bid me.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: O, stay but till then!

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: ‘Then' is spoken; fare you well now: and yet, ere I go, let me go with that I came for; which is, with knowing what hath passed between you and Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Only foul words; and thereupon I will kiss thee.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome; therefore I will depart unkissed.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And, I pray thee now, tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: For them all together; which maintained so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them. But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: ‘Suffer love,' a good epithet! I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart! If you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for yours; for I will never love that which my friend hates.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: It appears not in this confession: there's not one wise man among twenty that will praise himself.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in the time of good neighbours. If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: And how long is that think you?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter in rheum: therefore is it most expedient for the wise,-if Don Worm, his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary,-to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy. And now tell me, how doth your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Very ill.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And how do you?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Very ill too.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too, for here comes one in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Ursula
dialogues.line: Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old coil at home: it is proved, my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused; and Don John is the author of all, who is fled and gone. Will you come presently?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Will you go hear this news, signior?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eyes; and moreover I will go with thee to thy uncle's.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Is this the monument of Leonato?

dialogues.speaker: A Lord
dialogues.line: It is, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Epitaph. Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, Gives her fame which never dies. So the life that died with shame Lives in death with glorious fame. Hang thou there upon the tomb, Praising her when I am dumb. Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn. Song. Pardon, goddess of the night, Those that slew thy virgin knight; For the which, with songs of woe, Round about her tomb they go. Midnight, assist our moan; Help us to sigh and groan, Heavily, heavily: Graves, yawn and yield your dead, Till death be uttered, Heavily, heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Now, unto thy bones good night! Yearly will I do this rite.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good morrow, masters: put your torches out. The wolves have prey'd; and look, the gentle day, Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about Dapples the drowsy East with spots of grey. Thanks to you all, and leave us: fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Good morrow, masters: each his several way.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds; And then to Leonato's we will go.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed's, Than this for whom we rend'red up this woe!

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: So are the Prince and Claudio, who accus'd her Upon the error that you heard debated: But Margaret was in some fault for this, Although against her will, as it appears In the true course of all the question.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And so am I, being else by faith enforc'd To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all, Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves, And when I send for you, come hither mask'd: The Prince and Claudio promis'd by this hour To visit me. You know your office, brother; You must be father to your brother's daughter, And give her to young Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Which I will do with confirm'd countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: To do what, signior?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: To bind me, or undo me; one of them. Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior, Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: That eye my daughter lent her. 'Tis most true.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: The sight whereof I think, you had from me, From Claudio, and the Prince. But what's your will?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical: But, for my will, my will is your good will May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd In the state of honourable marriage: In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: My heart is with your liking.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: And my help. Here comes the Prince and Claudio. with Attendants.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio: We here attend you. Are you yet determin'd Today to marry with my brother's daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Call her forth, brother: here's the friar ready.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter, That you have such a February face, So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I think he thinks upon the savage bull. Tush! fear not, man, we'll tip thy horns with gold, And all Europa shall rejoice at thee, As once Europa did at lusty Jove, When he would play the noble beast in love.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low: And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow, And got a calf in that same noble feat, Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings. Which is the lady I must seize upon?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: This same is she, and I do give you her.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Why then, she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: No, that you shall not, till you take her hand Before this friar, and swear to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Give me your hand: before this holy friar, I am your husband, if you like of me.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: And when I liv'd, I was your other wife:  And when you lov'd, you were my other husband.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Another Hero!

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: Nothing certainer: One Hero died defil'd, but I do live, And surely as I live, I am a maid.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander liv'd.

dialogues.speaker: Friar
dialogues.line: All this amazement can I qualify: When after that the holy rites are ended, I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death: Meantime, let wonder seem familiar, And to the chapel let us presently.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I answer to that name. What is your will?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Do not you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Why, no; no more than reason.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Why, then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived; for they swore you did.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Do not you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Troth, no; no more than reason.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: Why, then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula, Are much deceiv'd; for they did swear you did.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: And I'll be sworn upon 't that he loves her; For here's a paper written in his hand, A halting sonnet of his own pure brain, Fashion'd to Beatrice.

dialogues.speaker: Hero
dialogues.line: And here's another, Writ in my cousin's hand, stolen from her pocket, Containing her affection unto Benedick.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: A miracle! here's our own hands against our hearts. Come, I will have thee; but, by this light, I take thee for pity.

dialogues.speaker: Beatrice
dialogues.line: I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told you were in a consumption.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Peace! I will stop your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Don Pedro
dialogues.line: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: I'll tell thee what, Prince; a college of witcrackers cannot flout me out of my humour. Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram? No; if man will be beaten with brains, a' shall wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it; and therefore never flout at me for what I have said against it, for man is a giddy thing, and this is my conclusion. For thy part, Claudio, I did think to have beaten thee; but, in that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruised, and love my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I might have cudgelled thee out of thy single life, to make thee a double-dealer; which, out of question, thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Come, come, we are friends. Let's have a dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives' heels.

dialogues.speaker: Leonato
dialogues.line: We'll have dancing afterward.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: First, of my word; therefore play, music! Prince, thou art sad; get thee a wife, get thee a wife: there is no staff more reverent than one tipped with horn.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight, And brought with armed men back to Messina.

dialogues.speaker: Benedick
dialogues.line: Think not on him till tomorrow: I'll devise thee brave punishments for him. Strike up, pipers!
